item.title: 3 Reasons You Shouldn't Make Your Own Decisions
item.description:
I was recently looking for a good meal replacement option to make sure I get enough calories and protein on days when I don't have the time to prepare a good meal. While this may seem like a non-issue, I've made a commitment to only eating whole foods, so it's a bit trickier than it seems. I know how to make this decision, because I've done it before and I'm certainly qualified, as a person who knows what's best for himself and as a trainer with a lot of experience dealing with nutrition. Yet, despite all that, my first inclination was to ask around with my trainer buddies, to check Paleo/Primal blogs, and to put the question to Twitter.

Even with the knowledge that I would make the best decision for myself without any input, I still wanted someone else to make the decision for me.

Because I'm the kind of person that questions my thinking process (in case you haven't picked up on that by now), I wanted to figure out why I felt the need to ask around. After all, I have rarely asked for input on what I should be doing for my own training. Ask 50 trainers what you should be doing and you'll get 50 different answers; it's really something you need to decide for yourself. Once you've done that, then find a trainer who can help you reach that goal. I find it's better to make my own decisions and my own mistakes.

I'm not saying outside input isn't valuable. When you want to learn something, definitely seek out qualified teachers. I saw that Gold Medal Bodies was teaching a lot of people to do previously unattainable gymnastics skills, so I got one of their programs. But when you're making a decision, you already have all the information you need, and you know yourself well enough to know what's good for you, then asking for additional input is just pushing it off.

So, why was I hesitating and looking for outside opinions? I came up with a few answers.

item.title: Don't Trust the Experts
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1553" align="alignright" width="281" caption="HA! Designs - Artbyheather on Flickr"][/caption]

When I was a child, I had an annoying tendency to question everything my teachers told me. This got me sent to the principle on more than one occasion. As an adult, I tried to suppress this habit and like the rest of us, very quickly became enamored of experts. Until last year.

After spending a few months working with so-called fitness experts, I was finally ready to become one myself by getting my Level 1 CrossFit trainer certification. I drove the presenters insane with my questions, because I knew that they were oversimplifying, leaving stuff out, or were just plain wrong. I had done my own research, from a number of different sources, and come to my own conclusions. I was not ready to drink the Kool-Aid, no matter how expertly prepared or convincingly presented.
